title: Insurance firm Aviva tells dad his cardiac arrest 'is not a critical illness'
text:

Health insurance giants Aviva are refusing to pay out a claim from a man who came close to death after suffering a cardiac arrest - because they say it is not a 'critical illness'.

Lee Norcross, 43, collapsed while playing squash at the end of August.

The barber had to be brought back to life with a defibrillator and faces a long road to return to normal life after being diagnosed with heart condition Dilated Cardiomyopathy.

Lee, who had a pacemaker fitted, will spend the rest of his life on medication.

He is unable to drive and, being self employed, can claim no sick pay, report the Manchester Evening News .

But things got worse when he found out there was a problem with his Aviva policy.

(Image: Manchester Evening News)

Lee signed up in 2007 on the promise that they would pay off his mortgage in the event of a critical illness such as a heart attack, stroke or cancer. He has been paying a £65 premium ever since.

He assumed a cardiac arrest and heart attack meant the same thing - but the company rejected his claim for a £90,000 payout saying it is not on the list of conditions covered.

In a further twist his friend Jason Morris, a financial adviser, discovered Aviva changed it's critical illness policy to include cardiac arrest in 2009. They say the new terms and conditions didn't apply to existing customers.

"I don't know when I'll be able to go back to work," he said.

(Image: Birmingham Post and Mail)

"My wife Sue is worried, I've got three kids but I thought 'at least we're covered' and then it turns out we're not.

"What did I pay all that money for? I can't drink, I can't play sport, I've got to take tablets for the rest of my life - it's pretty critical.

"It's a genuine claim."

He added: "I know a lot of people will get technical, But when you're a 30-year-old guy and you buy the policy and they say 'we'll send you a booklet', you don't know what you're going to get."

An Aviva spokesperson said: “We sympathise with customers experiencing significant health issues and look to pay as many claims as possible.

"Mr Norcross and his financial adviser notified us that Mr Norcross has suffered a cardiac arrest and they were informed that this particular condition is unfortunately not covered by the terms of his contract.

(Image: PA Archive/PA Images)

“Critical illness insurance is designed to cover a defined set of medical conditions, which are clearly stated at the outset of the insurance policy, and policy premiums are priced to meet a claim against these specific conditions, and not others.

"Although medical conditions included in a critical illness policy can change over time to reflect advances in medical care, it does not necessarily follow that a newer policy will provide more extensive cover overall.

"To be fair to all of our customers, we need to assess claims consistently and against the contract that the customer has.

“It is important that customers review their protection insurance periodically alongside their financial adviser, particularly if cover was arranged some time ago, to decide whether a new policy would be more appropriate and to be reminded of the conditions they are covered for.”
description: They knocked back Lee Norcross' claim but anyone who signed up to the same policy after 2009 will be covered
